Question_1.Context: Biopolymers extracted directly from nature are known as:
Question_1.Question: What are biopolymers directly extracted from nature called?
Question_1.Source: One major class of these sustainable polymers are biopolymers that are directly extracted from nature...

Question_2.Context: Which of the following is an example of a biopolymer extracted from nature?
Question_2.Question: Which of the following is a biopolymer directly extracted from nature?
Question_2.Source: Sustainable polymers also include polymers that are biologically or chemically synthesised from renewable sources of monomers, such as polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs) and polylactide (PLA).

Question_3.Context: Which type of sustainable polymer is biodegradable under composting conditions?
Question_3.Question: Which sustainable polymer is biodegradable under composting conditions?
Question_3.Source: Materials based on some sustainable polymers are biodegradable under composting conditions (e.g. PLA and PBS)...

Question_4.Context: What is a key property of chitosan that makes it extensively used in biomedical areas?
Question_4.Question: What key property of chitosan makes it extensively used in biomedical areas?
Question_4.Source: Biopolymers such as chitosan have been extensively used in biomedical areas due to their biodegradability...

Question_5.Context: What is the purpose of the freeze-gelated chitosan/hydroxyapatite porous scaffold described in the text?
Question_5.Question: What is the purpose of the freeze-gelated chitosan/hydroxyapatite porous scaffold?
Question_5.Source: Rehman et al. described the use of a freeze-gelated chitosan/hydroxyapatite porous scaffold to load heparin for the promotion of angiogenesis...

Question_6.Context: Which material was used to reduce the brittleness and increase the thermal stability of a foam made from PLA?
Question_6.Question: Which material was used to reduce brittleness and increase thermal stability in a foam made from PLA?
Question_6.Source: PBSA reduced the brittleness and increased the thermal stability of PLA.

Question_7.Context: What is the main reason for considering PLA as a substitute for petroleum-based polymers in making foams?
Question_7.Question: Why is PLA considered a substitute for petroleum-based polymers in making foams?
Question_7.Source: PLA has been considered as a substitute for petroleum-based polymers to make foams for various applications from packaging, cushioning, insulation, plastic utensils, to biomedical scaffolds.

Question_8.Context: What is the role of tungsten disulphide (WS2) nanotubes in the crystallization of PLA films?
Question_8.Question: What is the role of tungsten disulphide (WS2) nanotubes in the crystallization of PLA films?
Question_8.Source: They found that 0.6 wt% of WS2 induced the same level of crystallinity in as stretched PLA-WS2 as annealing in neat PLA for 10 min.

Question_9.Context: What is the purpose of lignin-derived porous graphene oxide-based nanocomposites described in the text?
Question_9.Question: What is the purpose of lignin-derived porous graphene oxide-based nanocomposites?
Question_9.Source: Hakkarainen et al. described free-standing three-dimensional lignin-derived porous graphene oxide (GO)-based nanocomposites with excellent adsorption capacity for heavy metal ions and cationic dyes.

Question_10.Context: What is a significant property of starch in the context of materials applications?
Question_10.Question: What is a significant property of starch in materials applications?
Question_10.Source: As an important biopolymer from biomass, starch can be converted into so-called 'thermoplastic starch' and has been extensively studied for materials applications...
